contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "her fall" is an idiom. Alternate translation: "Her downfall was astonishing" or "Those who saw her destruction were surprised" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Her fall was terrible

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "has taken possession of" or "has stolen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: has put his hand on

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "day" is used as an idiom. Alternate translation: "when he was fiercely angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: on the day of his fierce anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "heaven" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: on high

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "prevented my from walking any further" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: turned me back

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "I cannot resist them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I am not able to stand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "the day" is an idiom that refers to a specific event happening. Alternate translation: "You have done what you have promised" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: You have brought the day you promised

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a request for Yahweh to judge Jerusalem's enemies for their wickedness. The phrase "come before you" is an idiom. Alternate translation: "Pay attention to all of the wickedness they have committed" or "Judge them for all of their wickedness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Let all their wickedness come before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "day" is used as an idiom that refers to a general period of time. Alternate translation: "at the time when he displays his anger" or "at the time he acts in his anger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: on the day of his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "day" is used as an idiom that refers to a general period of time. Alternate translation: "the time of his anger" or "the time of his anger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the days of his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "have shouted victoriously" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: have raised a shout

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "I have cried until I cannot cry anymore" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: My eyes have failed from their tears

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "We have greatly desired to see it happen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: We have lived to see it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "pour out your heart like water" is an idiom. Here the Lord is represented by his "face" to emphasize his presence. Alternate translation: "Tell the Lord how you feel in your inner being" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Pour out your heart like water before the face of the Lord

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "to attack from every direction" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: on every side

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "day" is used as an idiom that refers to a general period of time. Alternate translation: "at the time when Yahweh acted in his anger" or "during the time that Yahweh displayed his anger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: on the day of the anger of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks about God refusing to listen to his prayers as though God was shutting his ears so that the author's prayers could not go into them. Alternate translation: "he refuses to hear my prayer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: he shut out my prayer

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people in general. Alternate translation: "human beings" or "people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the children of mankind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) the women of Jerusalem or 2) all the inhabitants of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: all the daughters of my city

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Remember" here is an idiom. Alternate translation: "Yahweh, think about what has happened to us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Remember, Yahweh, what has happened to us

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase "given ourselves" is an idiom. Alternate translation: "We have made a treaty with Egypt and with Assyria so that we would have food to eat" or "We have surrendered to Egypt and to Assyria to have enough food to remain alive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: We have given ourselves to Egypt and to Assyria to get enough food

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "always" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: from generation to generation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this idiom refers to the duration of God's life. Since God lives forever, it can also be translated as "forever." Perhaps the writer was uing hyperbole and exaggerating the length of time he believed that God was forsaking them. Alternate translation: "for as long as you live" or "forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: for the length of your days
